div1.head: Article on Camp Lazear Building No. 1, by Frank Carey, [June, 1950]
div1.p:
By Frank Carey
Associated Press Science Reporter

Washington, --(AP)--Wanted: $50,000 to $100,000
to preserve a “rotting” little building in Cuba which saw one of
the most dramatic adventures in history a half century ago.

It is one of the two structures in which Major Walter
Reed and his associates conducted final experiments in 1900
leading to the conquest of yellow fever.

The researches of Reed and his colleagues--with the
aid of heroic volunteers--demonstrated that yellow fever is
transmitted by a mosquito and is not contagious as had previously
been believed. This led to effective measures for the control
of the great plague.

Still standing today, near the town of Quemados, not
far from Havana, is a small wooden building in which volunteers
underwent a gruesome experience which exploded the theory that
yellow fever could be contracted from “fomites”--the soiled
and bloody bedding and clothing of fever victims.

The second building, in which some men were exposed
to the bites of infected mosquitoes, has long since disappeared--
believed to have been destroyed by a hurricane.

“Building No. 1”--the “infected bedding building” where
heroic volunteers slept for 21 nights without contracting fever--
was “rediscovered” in 1940 by Dr. Philip S. Hench of the Mayo
Clinic and two companions. One of the latter was “Johnny” Moran,
one of the original volunteers who got yellow fever from exposure
to infected mosquitoes.

Dr. Hench, who himself has contributed much to
humanity by his researches on cortisone and ACTH, the drugs
which have shown dramatic promise against arthritis and
certain other diseases, has made an avocation of the Walter Reed
Epic.

For a decade now, he has sought vainly to have some-
thing done about preserving the ancient building--all that
remains of the “battlefield” of the great experiment.

The Cuban government, he says, has designated this
“old warrior” as a national monument, but so far has not done
anything about its actual preservation.

But “it is falling to pieces and being allowed to rot,”
Hench said, adding:

Hench says he volunteered to stand the cost of
temporarily fortifying the structure with galvanized iron until
more lasting preservation could be made. But he said this
offer was politely declined because the Cubans wished to do this
work themselves. He said the Cuban government at one time
allocated $50,000 for protecting the building and laying out
the grounds, but all this was some time ago--and nothing has
happened since.

Hench has vainly tried to interest certain American
Philanthropists. He also has sought aid from the army, in
whose name Reed did his monumental research. So far, no funds
have been forthcoming.

“That is where the matter stands and it is a darn
shame,” Hench told a reporter.

“I haven't had the time to go out and collect nickels
and I haven't found a millionaire with $50,000 or $100,000.
Yet here a little building which saw one of the most dramatic
adventures in history is being allowed to rot.”
